images.caption: Chroococcus belongs to unicellular blue-green algae. It can be found in fine sediments – so-called epipelon. All blue-green algae reproduce asexually, by binary fission, separation of cells (exocytes) and separation of filament pieces (hormogonia). Photo: Prof. Aloisie Poulíčková

Filamentous types of blue-green algae can also be found in the mud, e.g. Komvophoron, Pseudanabaena, Oscillatoria, Phormidium. The picture shows two different species of the genus Komvophoron, along with an Euglena and a diatom. Photo: Prof. Aloisie Poulí
A typical example of benthic blue-green algae. It is named for the oscillation in its movement. Photo: Prof. Aloisie Poulíčková
Oscillatoria reproduces by few-cell filament pieces, so-called hormogonia. Photo: Prof. Aloisie Poulíčková
Blue-green algae of the genus Nostoc live in moist soil on a fishpond bank. They are able to fix air nitrogen. Photo: Doc. Petr Hašler
The genus Microcystis belongs to blue-green algae creating the so-called algal bloom. Dark spots in the cells are gas vesicles enabling the blue-green algae to float. Photo: Prof. Aloisie Poulíčková

Anabaena is a genus of filamentous blue-green algae. The picture shows vegetative cells (small ones with grainy content), akinetes – cells specialised for surviving unfavourable conditions (large cells with grainy content) and heterocysts – cells with transparent content, serving to gather air nitrogen, similarly as known in root nodule bacteria. Photo: Doc. Petr Hašler
